results.title: And the lighthouse made three
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, colour and audio
results.brief_description: A plasticene animated film about a lonely lighthouse, a craggy old lighthouse keeper and a mysterious dark figure that moves in the fog. A delightful song ends this tale of unrequited love.

results.title: Ashputtle: or the mother's ghost
results.brief_description: A mother does what has to be done to help her daughter - even if it means returning from the grave. A retelling of a traditional folktale (Grimm’s ‘Ashputtle’ as reworked by Angela Carter). Ashputtle is an unloved, uncared for and barely human child until her dead mother rises from the grave to look after her. It is a beautifully cut-out animation that explores themes of identity, responsibility, disintegration and transformation, in a bold and vibrant visual style.

results.title: Blow-up
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, black and white and audio
results.brief_description: ‘Blow up’ is a visual pun. Austrian experimental film-maker, Siegfried Fruhauf, uses discovered footage of a man demonstrating mouth to mouth resuscitation on celluloid. The film is displayed in a way that show-cases the celluloid format as an object, rather than viewing the film with the content frame by frame. As the footage rolls the film is objectively abstracted with penetrating sounds of heavy breathing. As the ‘camera’ pans closer, the image takes over and we enter the film. It is our breath that now fills the image.

results.title: The Golden Dark Age of Reason
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, black and white and audio

results.title: Film Ist
results.creator_credit: LOOP TV-Video-Film, Manfred Neuwirth and Gustav Deutsch
results.brief_description: Austrian filmmaker Gustav Deutsch is one of contemporary cinema’s pre-eminent avantgarde artists. After several years combing a massive archive of scientific films, Deutsch released ‘Film Ist (1-6)’, a film made up of found footage edited together into extraordinary assemblages of sound and image. The fragments of film traverse a vast range of human experimentation with time, light, motion, and the human form. We see vocal chords at work while we hear a singer rehearsing. As if peering into the suppressed memory of cinema itself, we see an eye being excised from the socket, the slow motion movement of apes, bullets, children and cats, and the world offered back to us as a phantasmagoria of wave forms, wind patterns, lightning flashes and electrical currents. Cinema was born out of scientific endeavour and has since redefined so much of how we understand the physical and temporal properties of the world. ‘Film Ist’ is a remarkable surrealistic report on cinema’s own memory of its mysterious role in the creation of the modern world.

results.brief_description: A memory film set in Belfast in 1981 during the IRA hunger strikes which led to the death and eventual martyrdom of Bobby Sands. Quiet and powerful, ‘81’ contains multiple points of view, alternating between Catholic and Protestant, women and men, youth and adults. What lingers and what haunts are the vivid stark images of the prisoners’ gaunt faces on the television sets; the determined set of Thatcher’s jaw; Bobby Sands’ eyes staring out from the posters glued haphazardly on the Belfast streets.

results.title: Dottie gets spanked
results.brief_description: Todd Haynes’ black comedy is set in 1950s suburbia where the TV heroine Dottie reigns supreme. When a young boy gets his chance to meet his idol, the series of events he witnesses transforms his fantasy life. This is where childhood’s end begins.

results.title: AstroTurf
results.creator_credit: Magnetic Monster Video, Australian Film Commission, Rod Bishop and Ian Haig
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, colour and audio
results.brief_description: ‘AstroTurf’ is a 3-D animation that tours through periods of time that mark different technologies, from the prehistoric to beyond the 21st century. As the technology advances, human evolution is virtually at a standstill, always at odds with the technology that is demonstrated to be fallible. Ian Haig uses bold graphic style drawing on influences such as; 1950s television, sci-fi imagery, computer games, cartoons and comic books. ‘AstroTurf’ becomes a platform to celebrate computer imaging and the alternate aesthetics that the medium allows for.

results.title: Blood
results.brief_description: Travelling through Australia with his film camera, Ivan Sen has visited many Aboriginal communities, from urban to prison to distant-rural. Photographing people in their definitive environments, he has created an installation which is a subtle and deeply moving meditation on skin, landscape, gesture and the many nuances of Aboriginal identities.
